texts.definition: Games that have more than one player.
markups: <style="Definition">Games that have more than one player.</style>

Most games let several players participate in the gameplay, either against each other or working together towards a common goal. Before the emergence of video games basically only puzzles were not multiplayer games, and even so many single-player video games also have multiplayer support. With the advent of the internet it became practical to create <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with hundreds or thousands of players, first in MUDs<ref name="MUDs"/> and later in MMORPGs<ref name="MMORPGs"/>.
Besides giving people other humans to compete or cooperate with, <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> let people have social interaction before, during, and after play sessions.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> has two players competing against one another by taking turns. The board games <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> let players compete against the game system, while tabletop roleplaying games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> allow players to fight enemies controlled by a game master.

Computer and console games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> or the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20series">Need for Speed series</link></style> allow players to compete against each other in combat or races. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> also offers team-based variants where groups of players fight each other, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike%20series">Counter-Strike series</link></style> and games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%201942">Battlefield 1942</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style> are dedicated to this type of gameplay. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> is structured to let a 4-person team struggle against people turned murderous by an infection. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lego%20Star%20Wars%20series">Lego Star Wars series</link></style> is optionally a <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Game</style> in that a second player can jump in and out of gameplay as wanted. Even single-player computer games can be considered as multiplayer games on one level if they make use of high score lists, as for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Icy%20Tower">Icy Tower</link></style>.

MMORPGs such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Eve%20Online">Eve Online</link></style> can have thousands of players playing the same game instance simultaneously and tens or even hundreds of thousands of players participating in the game instance asynchronously.

Games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Battle">Warhammer Fantasy Battle</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> where every player own parts of the set of allowed game elements, and when some players wish to play each of these build and bring collections which adhere to agreed upon construction rules.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Clash%20of%20the%20Princes">Clash of the Princes</link></style> is a rare example that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Gamebooks">Gamebooks</link></style> can be <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style>.

For <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> to be played, players need to be able to organize themselves to participate together in the activity. In most cases this needs to be done by the players themselves but those with <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style> support players not being co-located through <style="Link"><link="game-servers">Game Servers</link></style> and this may make it desirable to support the players in being able to find each other through support systems; <style="Link"><link="meta-servers">Meta Servers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="friend-lists">Friend Lists</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="game-lobbies">Game Lobbies</link></style> are examples of this and can let players choose from <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style> also makes possible some more specific design solutions regarding narration, e.g. using <style="Link"><link="phasing">Phasing</link></style> to let players experience stories in a game without this affect other players. <style="Link"><link="synchronous-gameplay">Synchronous Gameplay</link></style> by their nature require <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style>, as there must be several players sharing the same game situation. Unless a <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Game</style> is supposed to be an <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Game</link></style>, it can either make use of <style="Link"><link="winner-gameplay-ends">Winner determined after Gameplay Ends</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="winning-ending-gameplay">Winning by Ending Gameplay</link></style>.

When one considers players, it is most common to think about humans. However, any type of <style="Link"><link="agents">Agent</link></style> can be a player so <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> can be used to simulate other players to allow <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> that can be played alone (this is for example done in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>). If this is experienced as a <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Game</style> or a <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Game</link></style> is however dependent on the human player's ability to notice their behavior as well as focus upon <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>. For added flexibility, games may allow <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> functionality to let human players and <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> switch control of who is playing, but this risk affecting <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> negatively, and may lead to specific instances to feel like <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> need <style="Link"><link="summary-updates">Summary Updates</link></style>, this can in addition cause <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> to the other players (as may for example be the case when a new or late players joins a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Game</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>. Supporting very many players, as <style="Link"><link="massively-multiplayer-online-games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> do, have additional challenges and needs.

Given that <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-starting-conditions">Asymmetric Starting Conditions</link></style> may more or less be impossible to avoid (especially if <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> are allowed), designers of <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> need to consider how much this should be allowed to affect the overall gameplay, and how to achieve the wanted level of asymmetry.

A basic decision regarding <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> is if the primary gameplay resolves around <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style> (Players vs. Environments) as in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> (Players vs. Players) as in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> gameplay is typically design around <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> between the players or <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style>; the use of <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> is a common way of achieving the latter and <style="Link"><link="secret-scoring-mechanisms">Secret Scoring Mechanisms</link></style> can be used to cause uncertainty of who is leading in these cases. <style="Link"><link="secret-goals">Secret Goals</link></style> can in general achieve the same effects as <style="Link"><link="secret-scoring-mechanisms">Secret Scoring Mechanisms</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> games can make use of <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, as in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%201942">Battlefield 1942</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style>, which can be combined with <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style> gameplay as in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients%20series">Defense of the Ancients series</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> can also be used to support <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> gameplay but can equally well support <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style>. In both cases, they support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> and by that also <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>. To encourage <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> further in these types of games, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Abilities">Asymmetric Abilities</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> can either suggest or require <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> through a use of <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> of abilities to enable <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>; <style="Link"><link="crossmedia-gameplay">Crossmedia Gameplay</link></style> can effectively be used for these purposes since it can create <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style>. These solutions may be of a more permanent nature through the use of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (possibly influenced over time through <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>) or more context-dependent. A specific example of the latter is <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asymmetric%20Roles">Asymmetric Roles</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>, e.g. the division between driving vehicles and manning the weapons mounted on them in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> may also allow for <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> by allowing <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style> as well as individual <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> to develop over time. When the games also have <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="massively-multiplayer-online-games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Community%20Functionality">Community Functionality</link></style> supports <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Group%20Belonging">Group Belonging</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="friendly-fire">Friendly Fire</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Inherent%20Mistrust">Inherent Mistrust</link></style>, and the possibility of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sabotage">Sabotage</link></style> can be used when making games where one wishes to limit the amount of <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> or make it more difficult within <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>. Any <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Game</style> with <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals or having events leading to the destruction of players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or other types of <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> needs to consider if <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style> is wanted or how this should be avoided by inserting players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> again through <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>. Similar issues need to be regarding in <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> or those where players can perceive <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-game-states">Unwinnable Game States</link></style> (true or not) since these will result in <style="Link"><link="early-leaving-players">Early Leaving Players</link></style> (and designers might want to consider this for all types of <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> to counter the effects of <style="Link"><link="early-leaving-players">Early Leaving Players</link></style> in general). One reason why <style="Link"><link="early-elimination">Early Elimination</link></style>, which can be both in the form of <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="team-elimination">Team Elimination</link></style>, can be wanted is that one wants to use the <style="Link"><link="last-man-standing">Last Man Standing</link></style> goal so that the last player(s) having <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> left wins. <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> is probably the most classic way of achieving <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competitions">Competitions</link></style> rather than <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> games, and this does so by creating <style="Link"><link="symmetric-goals">Symmetric Goals</link></style> for them. The use of <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> offers another design possibility regarding this.

Unless a <style="Link"><link="possibility-anonymity">Possibility of Anonymity</link></style> is aimed for, it is important for <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> to help players identify each other, e.g. making <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> unique through attaching <style="Link"><link="handles">Handles</link></style> or allowing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar%20Personalization">Avatar Personalization</link></style>. One reason for this is that players typically need to engage in <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> or other types of <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bragging">Bragging</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> even in those where there is no <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>. While games played with the players located in immediate proximity of each other can make use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style>, online games typically achieved this through providing the possibility of different types of <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Defined%20Vocabulary">Game-Defined Vocabulary</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> makes <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> easier regardless of players' actual location, and can be achieved either through <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> found in games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Virtual%20Co-Presences">Virtual Co-Presences</link></style> also supports this, and can be encouraged by <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> to locate each other (as done in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>). Having <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> can help provide common points of reference to help <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style>, point out potential rewards of <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>, and the risks of <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>. In contrast, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/ESP%20Game">ESP Game</link></style> relies on players not being able to directly communicate with each other so it takes precautions to not match players together with network addresses which may indicate close proximity to each other.

<style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> opens up the possibility for <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="trick-taking">Trick Taking</link></style>, and some of these can include game rules related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distributions">Player-Decided Distributions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Decided%20Results">Player Decided Results</link></style>. This can easily led to <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> but some <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style> games intentionally introduce this, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Republic%20of%20Rome">The Republic of Rome</link></style> that pit players individual goals against that of the group or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Intrigue">Intrigue</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/So%20Long%20Sucker">So Long Sucker</link></style> which more or less force players to betray each other. In <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>, similar effects can arise if players have the possibility of rescuing each other.

In games with large <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, players may not encounter each other unless the design of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> promotes this. Examples of features that can be used to herd players together are <style="Link"><link="arenas">Arenas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>, and (quite naturally) <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style>.

Many design choices are unique to <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> or are significantly modified by the presence of other players: <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> and providing <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> can be more difficult to achieve, especially when <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> is possible, although <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> (for example through <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> and either <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player%20Decided%20Results">Player Decided Results</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distributions">Player-Decided Distributions</link></style>) and systems for <style="Link"><link="dynamic-difficulty-adjustment">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</link></style> can help. Issues which can make <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>

especially difficult are <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>. This since advantages can multiply over time and new players may have to compete with those that have played for a long time. The issues of learnability and <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>, and in general having <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, can be addressed through <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="asymmetric-resource-distribution">Asymmetric Resource Distribution</link></style> and differences in <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> (although these can also be the original source of the imbalances). <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> and to a lesser degree <style="Link"><link="entitled-players">Entitled Players</link></style> can be used for this and can allow the other players greater <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>. An oddity for <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> is that <style="Link"><link="sanctioned-cheating">Sanctioned Cheating</link></style> does not have to be for personal gains, players may engage in it also to maintain <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> have the possibility of using <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, as for example done by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Battle">Warhammer Fantasy Battle</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Magic:%20The%20Gathering">Magic: The Gathering</link></style>. This is typically combined with <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> to allow <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> and setting up for <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>, and leads to <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style> and that players share <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> as a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style>.

Although it may seem that the main requirement for <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> is that the game supports several players, even <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> can be a possible foundation for making <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style>. This can be accomplished through <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> such as organizing players in <style="Link"><link="tournaments">Tournaments</link></style>. Another form of <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style> that make <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> into <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> are those that share <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High Score Lists</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="ghosts">Ghosts</link></style>. Finally, many <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> are packaged together with <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> (it can be argued if they are single games or not), making use of the same game elements, rules, interface, and skill sets required.

From a pure game mechanic point of view, games allowing <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay can provide difficulties maintaining <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, especially if <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> is used. One possible solution is the use of <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> of take players' roles when they leave and that new players take over <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> positions. Another problem regarding this occurs if <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> is present, since players may break the theme dictated by the game if not acting according to their characters' personalities, and in this case players may even break <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> by describing or enacting things that do not exist or take place in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>.

Most <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> need additional interfaces to provide the <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> needed for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style>, e.g. voice chats to give near <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> or quick message systems of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Defined%20Vocabulary">Game-Defined Vocabulary</link></style> to control what information is passed. An exception to this is games that use <style="Link"><link="split-screen-views">Split-Screen Views</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="hotseating">Hotseating</link></style>, which either enable multiplayer gaming or allow players alternatives to how to play the games together.

<style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> are more cumbersome to use in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style>, since players must negotiate when to load previous game states.

For <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> there lies a risk of some players' <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> regarding how the narration progresses may be less than others. Further, combining <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> with letting players affect the outcome of the story becomes more and more difficult the more players can take part of a game instance.

<style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> is a necessity to have <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style> in games. The pattern also provides a focus point for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> between the players and lets them experience <style="Link"><link="togetherness">Togetherness</link></style> in the activity of gaming, especially in situations when they can experience <style="Link"><link="spectacular-failure-enjoyment">Spectacular Failure Enjoyment</link></style> together or during <style="Link"><link="lull-periods">Lull Periods</link></style> when they with ease can focus more on each other. This can also occur in the retelling of <style="Link"><link="game-instance-stories">Game Instance Stories</link></style> provided by the <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style>). However, these can make the use of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> more complex. It provides the basic requirement for <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style> to emerge and makes it likely that <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> are useful or needed, but may require more specific patterns to ensure these pattern's presence. Many more specific experiences and activities are provide by <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> as well, but then typically depend on if the games make use of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Collaboration">Collaboration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style>, etc.  They however give players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Organizations">Social Organizations</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Identification">Identification</link></style> within the gaming groups (the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> if it exists, becomes more structured if <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> exists). By doing so they often give rise to <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> without any special attention to these features by designers (designers that wish to avoid this may explicitly design for <style="Link"><link="enforced-player-anonymity">Enforced Player Anonymity</link></style>). One example of this can be the trading of <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> before, during, and after game sessions. The <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> players have in acting can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> in games that support <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, and this <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> can add additional levels to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> but may also allow players to break the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> of the game setting.

Looking at more gameplay specific aspects, having several players in a game allows the game design to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> - while <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> have <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style> to motivate players supporting each other, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style> goals. These all modulate <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> by making it possible for players to develop specific <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> for their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and these <style="Link"><link="competence-areas">Competence Areas</link></style> are likely to give players <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> also provide some forms of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>, some which are not applicable in other games, for example <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> related to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>. One reason for such <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> can be the possibility of achieving <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style> which can exist when <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> or differing <style="Link"><link="skills">Skill</link></style> levels exist. The possibility of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> and use of <style="Link"><link="social-skills">Social Skills</link></style> also provide a platform to creating gameplay focused on <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>, and when this occurs it can give entrusted players an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>. Similarly, <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> where players can rescue other players from <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style> can give the potential rescuers an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style> also force players to make <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> considerations regarding the trust and possibility to fulfill obligations, as does other pattern such as <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Uncommitted%20Alliances">Uncommitted Alliances</link></style> which depend on social agreements. <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> creates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations as well but here because the players are both threats and potential victims to each other. As with any other situation with many people, <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> can also lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Excluding%20Groups">Excluding Groups</link></style> and this may be more likely in games where the gameplay allows or promotes unsocial behavior or ganging up. The uncertainty of what other players' made do in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> can give the effect of players feeling <style="Link"><link="luck">Luck</link></style> when they perceive what the other players actually do.

<style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> requires players to engage in <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, taking into account the possible future behaviors of the other players, but depending on the number of actions and their predictability this may also modulate how easy it is to do the <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>. Since this may not be possible to do with high certainty, the pattern often instantiates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Planning%20Ability">Limited Planning Ability</link></style>. For the same reason, <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> are one of the simplest way of providing <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> in games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> under the assumption that skilled opponents can be found. However, the time spent by players planning in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> may cause a lessening of players' <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> due to enforced <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> and some instances of this may be regarded as <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style> - this is especially likely in games with <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> and is likely to become worse the more <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> is. <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> make other players into <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, and this is magnified in games with <style="Link"><link="game-over">Game Over</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="permadeath">Permadeath</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="player-elimination">Player Elimination</link></style> since this can terminate gameplay or force <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> for some players until the next game begins (as is the typical case in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style>). If players cannot return to gameplay (which can practically be the case if the waiting time is to long), using <style="Link"><link="game-over">Game Over</link></style> for individual players results in <style="Link"><link="unsynchronized-game-sessions">Unsynchronized Game Sessions</link></style>.

Viewing other players as <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> is also likely in those games that have <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-goals">Ephemeral Goals</link></style> since these allow <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> to emerge for the other players when they themselves appear.

The gameplay in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> naturally provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutual%20Experiences">Mutual Experiences</link></style> as long as the players have some direct interaction with each other, and often make individual <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutual%20Enemies">Mutual Enemies</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="team-accomplishments">Team Accomplishments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mutual-fubar-enjoyment">Mutual FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style>, or simply <style="Link"><link="team-strategy-identification">Team Strategy Identification</link></style> follows for <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> (and <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> in the case of <style="Link"><link="mutual-fubar-enjoyment">Mutual FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="helplessness">Helplessness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style> goals where one player can <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style> another can create <style="Link"><link="mutual-fubar-enjoyment">Mutual FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> from <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Multiplayer">Multiplayer</link></style> games without any actual requirements of the players cooperating. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Group%20Belonging">Group Belonging</link></style> is also likely to be experienced, and this may sometimes occur anyway since all players of a game instance can be seen as a group. When some players of <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> misbehave or simply the players cannot find common ground on how the games should be played, the use of <style="Link"><link="player-kicking">Player Kicking</link></style> can let the activity continue after removing some players. All of these effects of <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> also work towards making watching gameplay more interesting for <style="Link"><link="spectators">Spectators</link></style>. In contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> can easily have problems with supporting <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style> for individual players; <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay is one way to overcome this.

It can be difficult to have <style="Link"><link="extra-chances">Extra Chances</link></style> in <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> since letting one player undo an effect in a game easily disrupts the other players gameplay experience and may ruin their <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>. Similarly, <style="Link"><link="negotiable-play-sessions">Negotiable Play Sessions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-sessions">Negotiable Game Sessions</link></style> are not inherently compatible with <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> since one player leaving a game instance may unbalance or ruin the gameplay for the remaining players. Supporting <style="Link"><link="social-adaptability">Social Adaptability</link></style> can be problematic for <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> for the same reason, and in addition questions may appear about which rules to use or to change.

In <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> with <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>, players can have <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> between game instances by switch roles - something that provides <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> - but if roles are limited in number this can lead to <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>. This is also a case when <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style> will emerge from <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style>.

A potential issue with <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> based on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competitions">Competitions</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> is that players may perceive (correctly or not) that there exists <style="Link"><link="predictable-winner">Predictable Winner</link></style> in some game situations; the use of public <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style> is a common reason why this may occur.

While all <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> can result in <style="Link"><link="early-leaving-players">Early Leaving Players</link></style>, those that are <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-games">Unwinnable Games</link></style> are more or less guaranteed to have this pattern emerge.

<style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style> can be difficult to combine with <style="CurrentLink">Multiplayer Games</style> since what constitutes a good point to save can be difficult to figure out unless <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> between all players is part of the design.

Game Element Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hotseating">Hotseating</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Inherent%20Mistrust">Inherent Mistrust</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="massively-multiplayer-online-games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="meta-servers">Meta
